Opened issue "Add fuget.org link to package details page" (#7850) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
This is the issue tracking the community PR: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/7832 as it needs some UX and messaging work before going live.

Rationale for the feature: 
fuget.org shows API level data for the packages and lets you compare the APIs across versions. This has been super useful for developers and they have already been using this. It would make sense for developers to directly explore their package on fuget.org from nuget.org's package details page.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed pull request "[PROPOSAL] Tool to determine if a .nupkg has valid Microsoft metadata" (#7000) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
This is minimal effort to make a tool that will allow teams to check the metadata of their package before pushing it to nuget.org. This is optional but will help teams catch metadata problems before shipping.

We can formalize the tool later, perhaps with `nuget.exe verify` and some kind of rules abstraction. But this is the cheap first step.

It's a old style tools package and requires .NET Framework 4.6.2. The .exe is here inside the package:

```
tools\NuGet.VerifyMicrosoftPackage.exe
```

In other words, it can be used like `NuGet.CommandLine` or `xunit.runner.console` where the user just hard codes the path inside the package of where the .exe is.

Teams with non-standard rules can specify a path to their custom rule set using `--rule-set`. We can communicate in a doc what owners have non-standard rule sets and what they are. There are 4 non-standard 4 rule sets in the PROD DB today.

We should also document that this does not cover author signature verification. This can easily be done with `nuget.exe verify -Signatures -CertificateFingerprint`.

## Open Questions

- How to know if the rules compiled into the tool are out of date?
   - We would release a new package to nuget.org after every master merge. Customers would just take latest package version
- Wouldn't a verify endpoint be easier? ðŸ± 

## Example output - invalid

Exit code is 1 (the number of bad packages).

```
Using the following package path argument:
C:\Users\jver\AppData\Local\Temp\NuGetTestFolder\5fda8093-4158-463b-b41e-de3e3b1fa2a1\inner\testA.nupkg

INVALID.
C:\Users\jver\AppData\Local\Temp\NuGetTestFolder\5fda8093-4158-463b-b41e-de3e3b1fa2a1\inner\testA.nupkg
The package TestPackage-65ed825e-dd81-4964-9599-f6a28d67171d 1.0.0 is not compliant.
There is 1 problem.
  - The package metadata defines 'Not Microsoft' as one of the authors which is not allowed by policy.

Valid package count: 0
Invalid package count: 1

The metadata validation used the following property names and JSON ruleset.

Readable .NET Name      | JSON Name
----------------------- | ----------
AllowedAuthors          | authors
AllowedCopyrightNotices | copy
ErrorMessageFormat      | error
IsLicenseUrlRequired    | licUrlReq
IsProjectUrlRequired    | projUrlReq
RequiredCoOwnerUsername | u

If question marks ('?') or weird characters appear below, consider using --write-default-rule-set.

{
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Incorrect error message when PDB does not match DLL" (#7844) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Describe the bug

A user wants to update their .snupkg associated with an already pushed package:
https://www.nuget.org/packages/tusdotnet/2.2.2

There is an existing .snupkg that was accepted but subsequent attempts fail with this error:

> The uploaded symbols package contains one or more pdbs that are not portable.

However upon closer investigation, the failure is not because the PDBs are portable but because the PEReader saw that the PDB and DLL do not match.

I think the error is here:
https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Jobs/blob/dbd927c309005b63b82c1017ff6bfcfec96434cf/src/Validation.Symbols/SymbolsValidatorService.cs#L251

This should use the error message `ValidationIssue.SymbolErrorCode_MatchingAssemblyNotFound`.

### To Reproduce

Upload a snupkg with a portable PDB that matches in name but does not match according to `PEReader.TryOpenAssociatedPortablePdb`.

### Expected behavior

The validation should fail with a more helpful error message.

### Screenshots

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/74369714-b2465200-4d8a-11ea-8bed-bffec4118b73.png)


### Additional context
Add any other context about the problem here.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Can't publish symbols because name collision on nuget.org" (#7848) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Describe the bug
I can no longer publish symbols on nuget.smbsrc.net because someone published (and later delisted) a package with the same name.

### To Reproduce
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Download MSI nupkg from https://dev.azure.com/heaths/public/_build/results?buildId=210&view=artifacts&type=publishedArtifacts
2. Regenerate my key (it had expired), copy it, and try to publish to wither www.nuget.org (either package or symbol package) or nuget.smbsrc.net (symbol package).

### Expected behavior
I can publish the symbol package.

### Actual behavior
I get an HTTP 403 error. Seems someone published https://www.nuget.org/packages/msi, which is the name of my package for powershellgallery.com. I've been publishing symbols this way for a while, but no longer can because of a name collision on nuget.org. There was never a need to publish the package to nuget.org (it's a PowerShell module). Seems authentication and authorization shouldn't necessarily be tied together. Is there some other way?

I can't seem to log into www.symbolsource.org anymore either. I can't remember account information (it's been a long time since I logged in), but http://www.symbolsource.org/Public/Account/SendPasswordMail says it requires a secure connection, but www.symbolsource.org doesn't respond via HTTPS.

### Additional context
Add any other context about the problem here.

Link to MSI package on PowerShell Gallery: https://www.powershellgallery.com/packages/MSI

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Can't publish symbols because name collision on nuget.org" (#7848) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Describe the bug
I can no longer publish symbols on nuget.smbsrc.net because someone published (and later delisted) a package with the same name.

### To Reproduce
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Download MSI nupkg from https://dev.azure.com/heaths/public/_build/results?buildId=210&view=artifacts&type=publishedArtifacts
2. Regenerate my key (it had expired), copy it, and try to publish to wither www.nuget.org (either package or symbol package) or nuget.smbsrc.net (symbol package).

### Expected behavior
I can publish the symbol package.

### Actual behavior
I get an HTTP 403 error. Seems someone published https://www.nuget.org/packages/msi, which is the name of my package for powershellgallery.com. I've been publishing symbols this way for a while, but no longer can because of a name collision on nuget.org. There was never a need to publish the package to nuget.org (it's a PowerShell module). Seems authentication and authorization shouldn't necessarily be tied together. Is there some other way?

### Additional context
Add any other context about the problem here.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Accessibility: Color-Contrast too low on package page" (#7847) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Describe the bug
I played around with [Accessibility Insights](https://accessibilityinsights.io/) and tried it on NuGet.org. The site seems (at least from the "Fast pass") quite good regarding accessibility, but the color on the package page for the currently released package is too low.

### To Reproduce
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. On this URL 'https://www.nuget.org/packages/Newtonsoft.Json/'
2. Perform this operation 'FastPass with https://accessibilityinsights.io/'
3. See error

### Expected behavior
"Congratulations!
No failed automated checks were found."

### Screenshots
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/756703/74595115-19d7f800-503e-11ea-8730-fb319a456680.png)

### Additional context
The link color and the background color (this blue-ish color) are problematic. I'm not sure if this combination is used on other pages as well. I would guess that the best fix would be to change the background color of the "bg-info" class. 

I could try to find a color combination, but I guess there is not "right" or "wrong", but if you would like that I should try something just give me a comment here. :)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Epic] Improve search results for Visual Studio (VS) client" (#7657) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Opened issue "nuget push does not accept absolute path of a package" (#9209) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used: NuGet.exe

NuGet version: 2.8.7.0

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. upload a package with full path.

2. nuget can not find the package because it always combine with current directory no matter it is an absolute path or a relative path.

```
cd /home/AnotherWorkSpace
nuget push /path/to/project/package.1.0.0.nupkg -Source "NuGet"
```

and say
```
Directory '/home/AnotherWorkSpace/path/to/project/package.1.0.0.nupkg' not found.
```
combine with current directory when specifing a absolute path is not right!

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "IncludeSource in .csproj doesn't work" (#9207) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I addthe **IncludeSource** configuration to the **.csproj** file and I also tried to set it on msbuild command line. The output nuget package does not contain project source code.

Sample project:
https://github.com/NetOfficeFw/NetOffice/blob/dev/netcoreapp30/Source/NetOffice.props#L30

Sample command line:
```
msbuild NetOffice.sln /t:Restore;Build;Pack /p:IncludeSource=true
```


According to the [documentation](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/tools/csproj#includesymbols) it should put source code to the nuget package.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Project fails to load after using PM Console" (#9203) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe):

version (x.x.x.xxx): All versions, at least since 16.4.5

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Create a new console project

2. Open the PM Console

3. `Install-Package Newtonsoft.Json`

4. Try to open the PMUI for the project again.

## Result

This error happens during `Install-Package`:
```
Install-Package : The operation failed as details for project ConsoleApp3 could not be loaded.
At line:1 char:1
+ Install-Package Newtonsoft.Json
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : NotSpecified: (:) [Install-Package], Exception
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : NuGetCmdletUnhandledException,NuGet.PackageManagement.PowerShellCmdlets.InstallPackageCommand
 ```

Additionally, once this happens, the PM UI becomes unusable, with this error any time you try to open it for that project:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17535/75078255-00a9ce00-54ba-11ea-8a94-cc9e95528caa.png)

## Notes

This seems pretty serious, but it doesn't always reproduce. I'm not really sure what's going on.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Inform when using preview features" (#9202) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Some features shipping in stable releases might still be in preview. We should inform users that they have enabled a preview opt-in functionality.

For example -  `<RestoreUseStaticGraphEvaluation>true</RestoreUseStaticGraphEvaluation>`

cc: @anangaur @jeffkl
